awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Resolution Analytical Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope for Materials and Engineering Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant supports the acquisition of a transmission electron microscope capable of high resolution imaging and elemental composition analysis. The instrument is housed in the new Physics and Astronomy Interdisciplinary Sciences building at the University of New Mexico (UNM) and is part of a university-wide suite of instruments devoted to materials research. The instrument benefits faculty investigators, students and post-doctoral associates from seven different departments on the campus. It provides opportunities to train graduate and undergraduate students in advanced methods of materials characterization. The greatly expanded capabilities for new types of analysis lead to a significant improvement in the kind of research that can be conducted. This instrument is the first open access aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscope (S/TEM) in the Rio Grande corridor and is available to researchers at other academic institutions and industry. UNM is a Hispanic Serving Institution, hence significant numbers of students from underrepresented groups (Hispanic and Native American) benefit from this facility. The instrument is integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses and also used for demonstrations aimed at K-12 students and teachers to enhance their interest in science and engineering.

Technical Description
The transmission electron microscope is equipped with spherical aberration correctors to enable a finely focused probe scanning across the specimen, allowing images obtained in S/TEM mode. In addition, the dual, large-area, x-ray detectors enable rapid acquisition of spatially resolved elemental composition maps. Research projects enabled by the instrument include studies of novel catalysts for exhaust emissions control and for energy storage, fuel cells using earth abundant metals, inorganic membranes that permit gas separation at elevated temperatures, nanoparticles for drug delivery, and interface defects in semiconductor materials used in solar cells and in optical communications. The microscope is also used to study the environmental impact of toxic metals from mine wastes. The development of novel alloy compositions for nuclear reactors, improved cements to fortify deep underground exploration in oil wells, and ultra-conductive metal nanocarbon composites is also enabled by this instrument.

This Major Research Instrumentation grant is supported using NSF funds allocated to the Division of Materials Research (DMR), Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems (CBET), and Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was the acquisition of a Transmission Electron Microscope (JEOL NeoARM 200CF) capable of high-resolution imaging and Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) at the University of New Mexico. The instrument was equipped with aberration correctors to enable a finely focused probe to be scanned across the specimen, allowing images to be obtained via Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM). The dual, large area, x-ray detectors enable rapid acquisition of spatially resolved elemental composition maps.  The instrument has been housed in the newly constructed Physics and Astronomy Interdisciplinary Sciences building and has now become part of a university-wide suite of instruments devoted to materials research.

The instrument has performed exceptionally well since it was installed and has had a high level of up time (>95%).  All visitors to this lab have been highly complementary about the design and performance of the laboratory space, noting the excellent stability of the image and very low noise (vibrational and EM). This was possible because the university provided funds for equipping the laboratory with a separate chaise to house utilities and a separate control room from where the instrument is operated.  In this manner, with a radiant cooling panel system and aluminum faraday cage, the instrument room could achieve the desired ambient temperature control and a vibration free and EM field-free environment and achieve its operating specification of 71 picometers in STEM annular dark field mode.

A major enhancement to the microscope was completed in August 2022 with the installation of a Gatan Continuum ER EELS/Imaging Filter system. The EELS system was purchased with funds from a NASA grant. As well as the spectrometer itself, the EELS system came with a new, more powerful computer in addition to the STEM-X 4D STEM software package from Gatan that enables simultaneous collection of EELS, EDS, nanodiffraction, and image data from each pixel in a STEM image. The combination of the EELS system with the 4D STEM enhances the analytical capabilities of the NEOARM substantially and provides a significant number of research opportunities.

In the period of this grant, the faculty PIs and the lab manager have trained 17 graduate students, as well as 21 senior personnel (faculty, postdoctoral scientists/research professors) and collectively this team performed TEM analyses on a wide range of samples for 57 additional unique users. Although most of these users came from UNM, the instrument has also been operated by 9 external users, from multiple different academic institutions, a national laboratory and four companies. Thus far, as a result of work done on this instrument, 30 manuscripts have been published (or accepted) and 2 manuscripts are under review. The research conducted using the TEM has been reported at national and international conferences.

The understanding of atomic scale structure of the various materials has enabled researchers to address important societal challenges. Specifically, research projects in materials sciences which include studies of novel catalysts for exhaust emissions control and for energy storage, low-cost fuel cells using earth abundant metals and inorganic membranes to permit gas separation at elevated temperatures to allow processing of gases derived from fracking. The microscope has also been used to conduct research in earth sciences, for example to study extraterrestrial samples, including samples returned by the JAXA Hayabusa2 mission and meteorites, and the work has addressed the possible health risks to local communities resulting from fugitive Uranium-bearing dust derived from abandoned mines.  The ability to image catalysts at the atomic scale has been used in several studies with the focus being the reduction of platinum group metals (PGM) content in emission control catalysts.  The instrument has strengthened biomaterials research to develop nanoparticles for pulmonary drug delivery. The instrument has allowed researchers to study how to minimize interface defects in semiconductor materials used in solar cells and in optical communications to optimize material properties. The development of novel alloy compositions for nuclear reactors, improved cements to fortify deep underground exploration in oil wells, and ultra-conductive metal nanocarbon composites have also benefited from the new instrument.

The instrument has also been used by users in local industry and start-ups from UNM, allowing them to study their materials and leading to economic impact in the community. The TEM has been used for outreach activities aimed at K-12 students and the general public, and for recruitment and retention of students at UNM.  The instrument has been integrated into courses taught at all levels, from freshmen to advanced graduate courses, so the campus as a whole has benefited.  This instrument is now a part of the Nanomaterials Characterization Facility at the University of New Mexico as a user facility.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2024
Modified by: Abhaya K Datye
